Package algorithms.sort

Class MiscSorter

java.lang.Object
algorithms.sort.MiscSorter
public class MiscSorter extends Object
first implemented in project https://github.com/nking/curvature-scale-space-corners-and-transformations w/ Copyright (c) 2014 Climb With Your Feet and using The MIT License (MIT) then moved to this shared library project which has the same copyright and license. NOTE: for a more efficient version of merge-sort that uses an auxiliary array to hold intermediate partial sorting, and uses insertion sort for the shortest segments in the divide and conquer pattern, see algorithms.correlation.UnivariateDistance._sortCheck().
Author:
nichole

    • ascSort

      public static int[][] ascSort(int[][] a, int sortByCol)
      copies the input array into an array of size one more column dimension and in that added dimension, stores the original indexes.
      Parameters:
      a - array whose rows will be sorted by column index. a cannot be jagged, that is, all rows must be same length;
      sortByCol - sort the rows of the array by this column index
      Returns:
      a sorted array of size [a.length][a[0].length + 1] where the last column has been added to hold the original row indexes.

    • ascSort

      public static double[][] ascSort(double[][] a, int sortByCol)
      copies the input array into an array of size one more column dimension and in that added dimension, stores the original indexes.
      Parameters:
      a - array whose rows will be sorted by column index. a cannot be jagged, that is, all rows must be same length;
      sortByCol - sort the rows of the array by this column index
      Returns:
      a sorted array of size [a.length][a[0].length + 1] where the last column has been added to hold the original row indexes.

    • nonRecursiveMergeSort

      public static void nonRecursiveMergeSort(double[] y)
      ascending sort array a by non-recursive merge-sort. It has O(n*lg(n)) runtime complexity and O(n) space complexity where n is a.length;
      Parameters:
      y - array to be ascending sorted

    • nonRecursiveMergeSortIndexes

      public static int[] nonRecursiveMergeSortIndexes(double[] y)
      calculate the order of indexes of y for ascending sort. The method does not sort y, and returns the indexes of y which put it in an acending sorted order. The method has O(n*lg(n)) runtime complexity and O(n) space complexity where n is y.length;
      Parameters:
      y - array
      Returns:
      the sorted index numbers of y

      Parameters:

      indexes - array holding the indexes for the sort order

      public static int[] mergeBy1stArgThen2nd(double[] a1, double[] a2)

    • sortBy1stArg

      public static void sortBy1stArg(int[] a, int[] b)
      use quicksort to sort a by ascending values and perform the same operations on b. Uses the optimized qsort3 from the book "Programming in Pearls" by Jon Bentley.
      Parameters:
      a -
      b -

    • sortBy1stArgThen2nd

      public static void sortBy1stArgThen2nd(float[] a1, float[] a2)
      sort by increasing value a1 and apply same changes to a2. Ties are further sorted by increasing values of a2. runtime is O(N * log_2(N))
      Parameters:
      a1 - array of points to be sorted
      a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also

    • sortBy1stArg2

      public static int[] sortBy1stArg2(long[] a1, long[] a2)
      sort by increasing value a1 and apply same changes to a2 using merge-sort. Ties are further sorted by increasing values of a2. The original indexes, sorted by the same swaps as a1 and a2 are returned. runtime is O(N * log_2(N))
      Parameters:
      a1 - array of points to be sorted
      a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also
      Returns:
      the original indexes, sorted by the same swaps that a1 and a2 received.

    • sortCCWBy1stPointLinear

      public static int sortCCWBy1stPointLinear(long[] x, long[] y, boolean reduceToUniqueAngles)
      sort the given points in place by polar angle in counterclockwise order around the first point x[0], y[0]. NOTE that the angles are rounded to degree integers for the "reduce to unique" step. The runtime complexity is O(n) where n = x.length.
      Parameters:
      x - array of x points
      y - array of y points of same length as x.
      reduceToUniqueAngles - if true, for any points having the same polar angle, only the point furthest from the first point in (x,y) will be kept. if false, all points are kept. for reference, 0.1 degrees = 0.001745 radians.
      Returns:
      the number of usable points in the sorted arrays. if reduceToUniqueAngles is true, then for points having same angle, only the furthest from x[0], y[0] is kept, and so there may be points at the ends of arrays x,y, and outPolarAngle that are unusable.

    • sortCCWBy1stPointLinear

      public static int sortCCWBy1stPointLinear(double[] x, double[] y, boolean reduceToUniqueAngles)
      sort the given points in place by polar angle in counterclockwise order around the first point x[0], y[0]. NOTE that the angles are rounded to degree integers for the "reduce to unique" step. The runtime complexity is O(n) where n = x.length.
      Parameters:
      x - array of x points
      y - array of y points of same length as x.
      reduceToUniqueAngles - if true, for any points having the same polar angle, only the point furthest from the first point in (x,y) will be kept. if false, all points are kept. for reference, 0.1 degrees = 0.001745 radians.
      Returns:
      the number of usable points in the sorted arrays. if reduceToUniqueAngles is true, then for points having same angle, only the furthest from x[0], y[0] is kept, and so there may be points at the ends of arrays x,y, and outPolarAngle that are unusable.

    • sortCCWBy1stPointLinear

      public static int sortCCWBy1stPointLinear(double[] x, double[] y, boolean reduceToUniqueAngles, double tolerance)
      sort the given points in place by polar angle in counterclockwise order around the first point x[0], y[0]. NOTE that the angles are rounded to degree integers for the "reduce to unique" step. The runtime complexity is O(n) where n = x.length.
      Parameters:
      x - array of x points
      y - array of y points of same length as x.
      reduceToUniqueAngles - if true, for any points having the same polar angle, only the point furthest from the first point in (x,y) will be kept. if false, all points are kept.
      tolerance - if reduceToUniqueAngles is true, tolerance is used to determing if two angles are equivalent. The angles are in radians and so is the tolerance. for reference, 0.1 degrees = 0.001745 radians.
      Returns:
      the number of usable points in the sorted arrays. if reduceToUniqueAngles is true, then for points having same angle, only the furthest from x[0], y[0] is kept, and so there may be points at the ends of arrays x,y, and outPolarAngle that are unusable.

    • reduceToUniquePolarAngles

      static int reduceToUniquePolarAngles(double[] x, double[] y, double[] polarAngle, double tolerance)
      traverse the polar angles in pA, and if points have the same polar angles within tolerance, only keep the one furthest from (x0, y0). NOTE that x, y, deg should have been sorted by polar angle before using this method. This method compacts arrays x, y, and pA are compacted so that the usable values are at the top r indexes where r is returned by this method
      Parameters:
      x - x coordinates of points
      y - y coordinates of points
      polarAngle - polar angles of points in x,y w.r.t to their first points x[0], y[0]. x,y,deg should have been sorted by polar angle before using this method.
      Returns:
      returns the number of indexes usable in each of x, y, and pA after compacting the arrays to remove redundant polar angle degrees.

    • relativeLengthOfLine

      static double relativeLengthOfLine(double x1, double y1, double x2, double y2)

    • sortCCWBy1stPointLinear

      public static int sortCCWBy1stPointLinear(long[] x, long[] y, boolean reduceToUniqueAngles, double tolerance)
      sort the given points in place by polar angle in counterclockwise order around the first point x[0], y[0]. NOTE that the angles are rounded to degree integers for the linear runtime. The runtime complexity is O(n) where n = x.length.
      Parameters:
      x - array of x points
      y - array of y points of same length as x.
      reduceToUniqueAngles - if true, for any points having the same polar angle, only the point furthest from the first point in (x,y) will be kept. if false, all points are kept.
      tolerance - if reduceToUniqueAngles is true, tolerance is used to determing if two angles are equivalent. The angles are in radians and so is the tolerance. for reference, 0.1 degrees = 0.001745 radians.
      Returns:
      the number of usable points in the sorted arrays. if reduceToUniqueAngles is true, then for points having same angle, only the furthest from x[0], y[0] is kept, and so there may be points at the ends of arrays x,y, and outPolarAngle that are unusable.

    • reduceToUniquePolarAngles

      static int reduceToUniquePolarAngles(long[] x, long[] y, double[] polarAngle, double tolerance)
      traverse the polar angles in pA, and if points have the same polar angles within tolerance, only keep the one furthest from (x0, y0). NOTE that x, y, deg should have been sorted by polar angle before using this method. This method compacts arrays x, y, and pA are compacted so that the usable values are at the top r indexes where r is returned by this method
      Parameters:
      x - x coordinates of points
      y - y coordinates of points
      polarAngle - polar angles of points in x,y w.r.t to their first points x[0], y[0]. x,y,deg should have been sorted by polar angle before using this method.
      Returns:
      returns the number of indexes usable in each of x, y, and pA after compacting the arrays to remove redundant polar angle degrees.
